webTitle: Shell soars after update while Tullow and Heritage Oil climb after deals

fields.standfirst: FTSE 100 edges higher after ex-dividends but oil sector in focus
fields.body:
Excitement in the oil sector with better than expected results from Royal Dutch Shell and deals for Tullow Oil and Heritage Oil.

Shell disappointed the market earlier this year with a profit warning, but under its new chief executive Ben van Beurden it has reported a jump in first quarter cashflows and a 4% rise in dividends. Earnings slipped 3% to $7.33bn but this was slightly higher than forecasts, before a $2.9bn charge relating to impairments on refineries in Asia and Europe. Van Beurden was cautious on the outlook, however. He said:

The impairments we have announced in downstream reflect Shell's updated views on the outlook for refining margins. There are substantial pressures on the industry from excess capacity, changing product demand, and new oil supplies from liquids-rich shales.

But analysts were mainly positive, and Shell B shares have jumped 109p to £25.40, the biggest riser in the leading index. Peter Hutton at RBC Capital Markets said:

Shell significantly beat our expectations, publishing adjusted net income of $7327m in the first quarter, compared with RBC's estimate of $4522m and Bloomberg consensus of $4954m.
The beat was reflected in most divisions, with upstream up 46% versus RBC estimates, R&M up 265% and Chemicals up 20%. Both volumes and realisations in the upstream were close to our estimates, suggesting that in addition to strong LNG trading results, much of the beat probably reflected lower costs. We have highlighted the potential that additional provisions may have been taken within divisions and experience suggests that the cumulative effect of this can be material; it is possible that some businesses were indeed cautious last year and this further benefited this quarter's result. We believe it is early for fundamental cost improvements, for which we believe Shell has significant opportunity, yet to show through.

At ING Quirijn Mulder said:

While the company foresees a return to robust returns it still notes the volatile macroeconomic environment it has to cope with. We have a hold as the year is not over and many steps have to be taken to show real underlying improvements.

At Tullow, which recently reported another disappointing drilling update, the company has sold majority stakes in two UK North Sea gas assets to Faroe Petroleum for $75.6m. It said it was looking for buyers for other North Sea operations to concentrate on oil production in new markets. Its shares are 23.5p higher at 889p.

Meanwhile Heritage Oil is 57.3p higher at 312.9p after it agreed a £924m or 320p a share offer from investment vehicle Al Mirqab Capital, run by the former head of Qatar's sovereign wealth fund.

On a busy day for company news and ahead of US GDP figures, the FTSE 100 has edged up 6.08 points to 6775.99.

The market has been slightly depressed by a number of companies seeing their shares go ex-dividend. These included Tesco, down 11p at 292.3p, Reed Elsevier, 26.5p lower at 856.5p and William Hill, off 9.7p at 337.5p.

Among the other businesses reporting, Next has climbed 70p to £65.55 after the retailed raised its annual guidance following a 10.8% rise in first quarter sales.

Rolls-Royce has risen 23p to £10.44 in the wake of confirmation after the market closed on Tuesday that it was in talks to sell its energy businesses, excluding the nuclear operations, for some €1bn to Germany's Siemens. Chris Dyett at Investec said:

We view the deal positively as Rolls is selling a business that has struggled to achieve scale and the cash will help fund the acquisition of Daimler's 50% stake of Tognum. However, this deal is unlikely to be a catalyst for a significant re-rating.

webTitle: Standard Life annuity sales halved after budget changes

fields.bodyText: Standard Life has reported a 50% slump in annuity sales after the chancellor's budget reforms scrapped compulsory annuities. George Osborne took the insurance industry by surprise when he announced in his March budget that pensioners would no longer be forced to use their savings pots to buy an annuity (an annual income). The change takes effect next April. Standard Life's chief executive, David Nish, said people with pension pots worth less than £10,000 were withdrawing their money, while those with larger pension pots are deferring the decision. He said: "While it will be some time before long-term trends become clear, the negative profit impact of the changes will reflect the relatively small size of our annuity business." Annuities contributed 6%, or £45m, to overall operating profits of £750m last year. Nish added: "The changes are very important and in many ways very positive for customers." But he criticised the way they were announced, which he said gave customers the sense that annuities were not worth having. The pensions minister, Steve Webb, said at the time that affluent people should be free to blow their pension pot on a Lamborghini even if this meant they ended up relying on the state pension. PricewaterhouseCoopers predicted in a report earlier this month that sales of annuities will collapse by 75%, from £12bn to £3bn, after conducting research among consumers aged 50 to 75. It found that three-quarters will not buy an annuity. Nearly 400,000 pension savers reach retirement every year, with pension pots averaging £30,000. Evidence from other countries where annuities are not mandatory also makes grim reading for the UK's £14bn annuities business. Only one in 25 Australians buys an annuity. In the US, most people also take their pensions as cash. Marcus Barnard, an analyst with Oriel Securities, said: "Standard Life has positioned itself to meet the long-term savings needs of its retail workplace, institutional and wholesale clients. It is not the largest annuity writer, but this line of business has helped its embedded value profitability." Prudential, Legal & General and Aviva are more heavily involved in annuities. L&G has said the budget changes would reduce annuity sales across the industry to £4.4bn a year. Standard Life said it had made a good start to 2014, with assets under administration up 1.5% to £247.8bn. Fee revenues have climbed 12% to £374m. The Edinburgh-based company said its position on Scottish independence had not changed since February, when it revealed that it had drawn up contingency plans to quit Scotland if it becomes an independent country. Nish said there was a "strong level of understanding" from customers. "We have not seen significant outflows from our business ... In the main the reaction has been that we did the right thing." Standard Life said in February it was very proud of its Scottish heritage – it has been based in Scotland for 189 years – but would "take whatever action we consider necessary" to protect its business, including transferring parts of its operations from Scotland.

It found that three-quarters will not buy an annuity. Nearly 400,000 pension savers reach retirement every year, with pension pots averaging £30,000.

Evidence from other countries where annuities are not mandatory also makes grim reading for the UK's £14bn annuities business. Only one in 25 Australians buys an annuity. In the US, most people also take their pensions as cash.

Marcus Barnard, an analyst with Oriel Securities, said: "Standard Life has positioned itself to meet the long-term savings needs of its retail workplace, institutional and wholesale clients. It is not the largest annuity writer, but this line of business has helped its embedded value profitability."

Prudential, Legal & General and Aviva are more heavily involved in annuities. L&G has said the budget changes would reduce annuity sales across the industry to £4.4bn a year.

Standard Life said it had made a good start to 2014, with assets under administration up 1.5% to £247.8bn. Fee revenues have climbed 12% to £374m.

The Edinburgh-based company said its position on Scottish independence had not changed since February, when it revealed that it had drawn up contingency plans to quit Scotland if it becomes an independent country. Nish said there was a "strong level of understanding" from customers. "We have not seen significant outflows from our business ... In the main the reaction has been that we did the right thing."

Standard Life said in February it was very proud of its Scottish heritage – it has been based in Scotland for 189 years – but would "take whatever action we consider necessary" to protect its business, including transferring parts of its operations from Scotland.

webTitle: Co-op Bank changes auditors after 40 years

fields.standfirst: Change was announced as a detailed report into Co-op by Sir Christopher Kelly criticised its accounting judgments
fields.body:
The Co-operative Bank is parting company with auditors KMPG, whose audit of the bank's accounts for 2012 is under investigation by the accounting regulator. The accounting firm has audited the bank's accounts for the past 40 years.

The change was announced as a detailed report into the events that led to the bank's emergency £1.5bn fundraising was published by Sir Christopher Kelly. He reveals that the bank, which is now just 30% owned by the Co-operative Group of supermarket, funeral homes and pharmacies, is on the City regulator's "watchlist".

Kelly devotes a whole chapter on accounting judgments, particularly three decisions he said illustrated the bank's consistent tendencies "to seek ways of favouring short term financial performance and capital where the bank believed the letter of accounting rules allowed it do so, even it that was not fully within their spirit".

The three examples are a bond issued by Britannia Building Society – which merged with the bank in 2009 – known as Leek; the way an overhaul of the IT systems was accounted for; and the way impairments on corporate loans were handled.

"With hindsight some of the accounting judgements might have proved to be inappropriate. But that does not necessarily mean that they were unreasonable at the time," Kelly said.

But he also said he had not looked at "detailed workings" of KPMG but referred to a review by the accounting regulator Financial Reporting Council (FRC) into the quality of the audits which found in early 2013 that the audit was "of an acceptable standard with improvements required".

In January 2014 the FRC announced it was conducting a formal review of the accounts that were audited by KPMG and that the investigation was likely to go back as far as 2008.

The Co-op Bank said it had put its audit out to tender earlier this year and that KPMG had not tendered. KPMG said: "Given the length of time that we have served the Co-op Bank as its auditor and the difficulties which the bank has faced in recent months, the fact that the bank has tendered its audit is understandable. We believe we have provided the bank with good service and robust audits over the years."

The bank said the investigation by the FRC was just one the reasons for the decision to replace the auditors.

It said the reasons included "the bank's separation from the Co-operative Group [for which KPMG remains the auditors]. The ongoing FRC investigation into the preparation, approval and audit of the financial statements of the bank for certain years up to and including the year ended 31 December 2012 and the board's intention to adhere to the forthcoming requirement to ensure companies put their audit work out to tender at least once every ten years."

The bank thanked KPMG "for the support they have given the new management team over the last 12 months".

webTitle: Co-op report: why bonuses mattered

fields.bodyText: Sir Christopher Kelly's report into how the Co-operative Bank was left with a £1.5bn capital shortfall last May contains a number of anecdotes, but one which he picks out relates to the way the accounts were drawn up for the 2011 financial year. He appears to be illustrating that bonuses mattered, even at the ethically motivated, mutually owned bank. Kelly points out that the additional provision would have had the effect of nearly halving the bank's £40m bonus pool for its employees and directors. "In February 2012, on a Friday afternoon, prior to the bank publishing its 2011 annual report and accounts, the bank finance team, risk team and CFO agreed that an additional £20m [of provisions for bad loans] should be charged against the corporate portfolio," Kelly writes. So, the finance team worked over the weekend to update the draft, only for the extra £20m provision to be reversed on the Monday morning. "The reversal was thought by some of those involved to have followed a conversation between the bank CEO and the group CEO. But there is no direct evidence of this," Kelly's report said. The bank's acting chief executive at the time, Barry Tootell, apparently ordered the reversal although he has no recollection of these events. The group chief executive, Peter Marks, denies any conversation took place. Before approving the annual report and accounts the audit committee was not told of this change and the auditor concluded that although the level of provisions was acceptable, the initial provision was towards the "more optimistic end" of the acceptable range. Does it matter? The finance team who worked over the weekend "were aware" of the effect that the £20m provision would have on the bonus pool, Kelly concludes.
